text:
If I were to make a 3d navigation game, something like <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M40rN7afngY> , how should I begin? I am a complete newbie to such a project, having no clue about 3d rendering or how to handle user input. The main purpose of this project is to use this game as an environment for reinforcement learning. This is more like a simulator, as opposed to a "game" that can be played and enjoyed by humans like normal games. But I would like to have interactivity via keyboard inputs.

What is the quickest way to prototype such a simulator? Should I use Makie.jl for this purpose?

Thanks in advance!

elements.text: If I were to make a 3d navigation game, something like

, how should I begin? I am a complete newbie to such a project, having no clue about 3d rendering or how to handle user input. The main purpose of this project is to use this game as an environment for reinforcement learning. This is more like a simulator, as opposed to a "game" that can be played and enjoyed by humans like normal games. But I would like to have interactivity via keyboard inputs.

What is the quickest way to prototype such a simulator? Should I use Makie.jl for this purpose?

Thanks in advance!

text:
Makie doesn't seem that appropriate. Let me ask some questions:
 - Do you want the renderer to be differentiable or not?
 - Do you want to pre render some frames offline and use them to in training or do you want the network to be trained while it's interacting with the environment?
 - Are you familiar with GPU programming?
 - Are you more CPU or GPU constrained?
 - Do the objects have to be 3d or would 2d shapes always visible for the player also be sufficient?
 - How many frames per second do you expect your network to eat?
 - What resolution will your network eat?

My general recommendation would be to write stand alone render code (rendering into an buffer) and tie that up with game logic. You can later use this bundle from your  training loop or take something like GameZero, throw your buffer to the screen and record input from the player. I would go with fixed time steps. As for how to accomplish this graphics style, it is awfully simiöar to Wolfenstein3d, here is a video with the ideas how to implement it <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eOCQfxRQ2pY>

Oh yeah a straightforward math implemenation should be good enough on modern processors

text:
If you were to do what the video does in Makie:
• You'd probably need to write your own 3d camera. One that reacts to key inputs rather than mouse inputs, has view bobbing and otherwise stays at a set height. This is probably not that hard, you can copy and paste what's there and adjust it to your needs.
• You probably want to avoid figures and axes and whatnot and just work with two overlapping `Scene()`s. One in pixel space (pixel camera), one in world space (3d camera) and the child one with `clear = false` so it doesn't draw over the other. Every plot should have `show_axis = false` (or `raw = false`?) to avoid creating axes. 
• If your inputs get complex and you need blocking inputs/events you may want to work with <https://github.com/JuliaPlots/AbstractPlotting.jl/pull/634> 
• Regarding plotting function it's probably just `mesh!` and m`eshscatter!` . Animated textures should work via observables, though that's probably not very efficient. 
• You can use `colorbuffer(screen)` and `depthbuffer(screen)` where `screen = display(scene)` if you need them. If you need/want the gl buffers you can get them from `screen.framebuffer.buffers`
• if you want to do things for each frame you can react to `screen.render_tick`
